root.pub-comments: The author calls this a cluster, which, according to him, is a grouping with time depth greater than 50 centuries which more than two scholar agree upon.

child.pub-comments: "Hivaro is one of the populous languages of lowland South America. The name Hivaro is the same as Shuara, and is a Hispanicization of an earlier indigenous pronunciation. Some linguists and anthropologists claim that all Hivaro is a single language, while ackknowledging that Awaruna is the most divergent dialect. The regional folk classification also distinguishes Awaruna from Hivaro. A defunct language and culture, Palta, is thought by Loukotka to have belonged within Hivaro, but it is poorly documented and shows little resemblance." (69) A language area is a geographic region where these languages are spoken, though the author does not quite consider them separate languages.

child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 69. London, New York: Routledge.

child.pub-comments: An emergent language is one included in a language area which does not appear to be quite distinct from the others. Speakers: 5000

child.pub-comments: "On the basis of a certain amount of lexical evidence, it seems that Taushiro might be related to both Omurano and Kandoshi, and more closely to the former." (69) Speakers: 7
